Completion Time Minimization of
Fog-RAN-Assisted Federated Learning With Rate-Splitting Transmission

Abstract

This work studies federated learning (FL) over a fog radio access network, in which multiple internet-of-things (IoT) devices cooperatively learn a shared machine learning model by communicating with a cloud server (CS) through distributed access points (APs). Under the assumption that the fronthaul links connecting APs to CS have finite capacity, a rate-splitting transmission at IoT devices (IDs) is proposed which enables hybrid edge and cloud decoding of split uplink messages. The problem of completion time minimization for FL is tackled by optimizing the rate-splitting transmission and fronthaul quantization strategies along with training hyperparameters such as precision and iteration numbers. Numerical results show that the proposed rate-splitting transmission achieves notable gains over benchmark schemes which rely solely on edge or cloud decoding.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, Fog-RAN, rate splitting, hybrid decoding, completion time minimization.

I Introduction

To alleviate the constraints on privacy and communication resources, centralized machine learning algorithms are envisioned to be replaced with distributed learning frameworks, in which distributed internet-of-things (IoT) devices collaboratively train a shared machine learning model while communicating with a cloud server (CS) [1]. In federated learning (FL), which is one of the most emerging distributed learning frameworks, IoT devices (IDs) upload locally trained models to CS [2, 3, 4, 5, 6]. Accordingly, we can protect the privacy of local dataset and save the spectrum resource. To avoid long latency required for exchange of local and global model updates between IDs and CS, edge learning has been actively studied, which enjoys low latency by bringing the decision-making tasks closer to IDs [7]. However, proximate edge servers should perform partial model aggregation with limited computing powers. In this work, we focus on the cloud-based FL at CS, which cooperates with a wider range of IDs and has more access to data. To alleviate the communication bottleneck, we address the signal processing design of IDs, distributed access points (APs), and CS for low-latency transmission on wireless and fronthaul links.

In [4], wireless communication for FL was studied under a single-cell scenario, in which IDs communicate with a single AP directly connected to a CS. More complicated scenarios with multiple APs were discussed in [3, 5]. The problems of minimizing the energy consumption at IDs were tackled in [4, 3], while the completion time minimization for FL was addressed in [5]. For the transmission over wireless channel, frequency division multiple access (FDMA) was assumed in [4], and non-orthogonal transmission across IDs was considered in [3, 5]. Regarding the fronthauling strategy, [3] assumed that the fronthaul links can carry the uplink received signals of APs to the CS without distortion and latency. This assumption can be made possible only when the fronthaul links have sufficiently large capacity compared to the uplink bandwidth. The work in [5] addressed a more challenging and realistic case, where the capacity of fronthaul links is limited. The edge decoding strategy is considered, whereby each AP decodes the messages sent by the associated IDs and transmits the decoded information on fronthaul. However, when the fronthaul links have sufficient capacity, cloud decoding would be a more efficient strategy, in which the fronthaul links carry quantized and compressed version of the uplink signals, and a joint cloud decoding at CS is followed.

In this work, we study FL over a fog radio access network (RAN), in which multiple IDs cooperate to handle a machine learning task by repeatedly uploading locally updated models to a CS through distributed APs. We aim at achieving the advantages of both the edge and cloud decoding strategies by adopting rate-splitting transmission at IDs. The effectiveness of the rate-splitting approach has been reported in [8, 9, 10, 11] in terms of overcoming the impairments caused by channel state information (CSI) uncertainty and generalizing existing multiple access techniques. The degrees-of-freedom (DoFs) region of the rate-splitting scheme was analyzed in [8] for multi-cell multiple-input single-output (MISO) interference channel (IC) with arbitrary CSI quality. A generalized linearly precoded multiple access scheme referred to as rate-splitting multiple access was proposed in [9] which subsumes conventional space-division and non-orthogonal multiple access schemes as special cases. In [10], the advantages of the rate-splitting transmission were studied for MISO broadcast channel (BC) with heterogeneous CSI qualities among users in terms of DoFs and average sum-rate. We refer to [11] for a comprehensive overview of rate-splitting techniques including appealing applications and standardization issues.

In this work, we study an application of the rate-splitting transmission for fog-RAN-assisted FL. In the proposed rate-splitting scheme, each ID splits its message into two submessages, which are encoded to independent data streams, and the two encoded signals are delivered to CS by means of superposition coding and edge and cloud decoding strategies. We minimize the competition time of the FL algorithm. Our design includes the joint optimization of the rate-splitting transmission and fronthaul quantization strategies along with hyperparameters of training algorithms, in particular, the algorithm precision and iteration numbers satisfying a target learning performance. Numerical results validate the advantages of the proposed FL system in terms of completion time.

Fig. 1 illustrates the overall procedure of the FL containing nGsubscriptğ‘›ğºn_{G} global iterations. Each global iteration consists of four steps: local computation at IDs; local model upload from IDs to CS through APs; model aggregation at CS; and global model broadcast from CS to IDs through APs. Individual IDs update their local parameter vectors using, e.g., the gradient descent (GD) method, with nLsubscriptğ‘›ğ¿n_{L} local iterations. Updated models are then sent to distributed APs through wireless uplink channels, and each AP conveys received local models to the CS via capacity-constrained fronthaul links. After aggregating local models, the CS broadcasts a global model to all IDs. These are repeated for nGsubscriptğ‘›ğºn_{G} global iterations.

III Rate-Splitting Transmission of Local Models

This section discusses the process of transmitting the locally updated models at IDs to the CS through distributed APs. One straightforward approach is a hard selection of decoding nodes for individual IDs. Each ID kğ‘˜k encodes the parameter vector of its local model into a single data message that can be decoded either by the serving AP iksubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜i_{k} (i.e., edge decoding) or the CS (i.e., cloud decoding). If the capacity CFsubscriptğ¶ğ¹C_{F} of fronthaul links is sufficiently large, it is desirable to select cloud decoding whereby the CS utilizes the uplink received signals of all the connected APs for centralized interference management. However, if the fronthaul capacity CFsubscriptğ¶ğ¹C_{F} is limited, the uplink signals reported to CS via fronthaul may contain quantization distortion noise of significant power. For this reason, for small CFsubscriptğ¶ğ¹C_{F}, it is better to perform local edge decoding at APs avoiding the quantization distortion, even at the cost of the degradation by interference signals [12]. This observation invokes the combinatorial optimization of selecting one of the edge decoding and cloud decoding strategies for every ID, requiring an exhaustive search over 2NIsuperscript2subscriptğ‘ğ¼2^{N_{I}} possible cases.

To achieve the advantages of both decoding strategies avoiding a complicated search, we adopt the rate-splitting transmission [8, 10] which softly combines these two extreme decoding policies. Such a hybrid design facilitates an optimized APs-CS coordination for the successful decoding of local machine learning models, thereby improving the quality of the model aggregation at the CS. This approach is particularly beneficial for finite CFsubscriptğ¶ğ¹C_{F} that suffer from the nontrivial tradeoff between fronthaul overhead and centralized interference management. The local model of ID kğ‘˜k is assumed to be represented in dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k} bits. Unlike the straightforward approach described above, ID kğ‘˜k divides the dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k} bits into two bit strings of size dE,ksubscriptğ‘‘ğ¸ğ‘˜d_{E,k} and dC,ksubscriptğ‘‘ğ¶ğ‘˜d_{C,k} bits, which satisfy

dE,k+dC,k=dk,dE,kâˆˆ[0,dk].formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘ğ¸ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‘ğ¶ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‘ğ¸ğ‘˜0subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜\displaystyle d_{E,k}+d_{C,k}=d_{k},\,\,d_{E,k}\in[0,d_{k}]. (7)

These bit strings are separately encoded to data signals ğ¬E,kâˆˆâ„‚MIsubscriptğ¬ğ¸ğ‘˜superscriptâ„‚subscriptğ‘€ğ¼\mathbf{s}_{E,k}\in\mathbb{C}^{{M_{I}}} and ğ¬C,kâˆˆâ„‚MIsubscriptğ¬ğ¶ğ‘˜superscriptâ„‚subscriptğ‘€ğ¼\mathbf{s}_{C,k}\in\mathbb{C}^{{M_{I}}} which are distributed as ğ¬E,kâˆ¼ğ’â€‹ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,ğE,k)similar-tosubscriptğ¬ğ¸ğ‘˜ğ’ğ’©0subscriptğğ¸ğ‘˜\mathbf{s}_{E,k}\sim\mathcal{CN}(\mathbf{0},\mathbf{Q}_{E,k}) and ğ¬C,kâˆ¼ğ’â€‹ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,ğC,k)similar-tosubscriptğ¬ğ¶ğ‘˜ğ’ğ’©0subscriptğğ¶ğ‘˜\mathbf{s}_{C,k}\sim\mathcal{CN}(\mathbf{0},\mathbf{Q}_{C,k}), respectively, under Gaussian channel codebooks. The purpose of the described message splitting and independent encoding is to incorporate both the edge and cloud decoding approaches in such a way that one signal ğ¬E,ksubscriptğ¬ğ¸ğ‘˜\mathbf{s}_{E,k} is decoded by the associated AP iksubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜i_{k} based on the local uplink signal ğ²iksubscriptğ²subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜\mathbf{y}_{i_{k}}, and the other signal ğ¬C,ksubscriptğ¬ğ¶ğ‘˜\mathbf{s}_{C,k} is decoded by the CS based on quantized signals received from all APs on fronthaul, which will be detailed in this section. Transmit covariances ğE,kâª°ğŸsucceeds-or-equalssubscriptğğ¸ğ‘˜0\mathbf{Q}_{E,k}\succeq\mathbf{0} and ğC,kâª°ğŸsucceeds-or-equalssubscriptğğ¶ğ‘˜0\mathbf{Q}_{C,k}\succeq\mathbf{0} are optimized along with the bit splitting variables dE,ksubscriptğ‘‘ğ¸ğ‘˜d_{E,k} and dC,ksubscriptğ‘‘ğ¶ğ‘˜d_{C,k}. Such an optimization policy can achieve performance at least those of edge decoding and cloud decoding schemes. ID kğ‘˜k transmits a superposition of the two signals ğ¬E,ksubscriptğ¬ğ¸ğ‘˜\mathbf{s}_{E,k} and ğ¬C,ksubscriptğ¬ğ¶ğ‘˜\mathbf{s}_{C,k}, i.e.,

ğ±k=ğ¬E,k+ğ¬C,k.subscriptğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğ¬ğ¸ğ‘˜subscriptğ¬ğ¶ğ‘˜\displaystyle\mathbf{x}_{k}=\mathbf{s}_{E,k}+\mathbf{s}_{C,k}. (8)

The constraints (17b), (17c), and (17d) impose that the computation time Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C}, the wireless transmission time Ï„Wsubscriptğœğ‘Š\tau_{W}, and the fronthaul transmission time Ï„Fsubscriptğœğ¹\tau_{F} are lower bounded by the right-hand sides (RHSs) of (4), (15), and (16), respectively. In order to make the constraint (16) more tractable, we have replaced the function giâ€‹(ğ,ğ›€i)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğsubscriptğ›€ğ‘–g_{i}(\mathbf{Q},\boldsymbol{\Omega}_{i}) in (16) with a variable RF,isubscriptğ‘…ğ¹ğ‘–R_{F,i} adding a constraint RF,iâ‰¥giâ€‹(ğ,ğ›€i)subscriptğ‘…ğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğsubscriptğ›€ğ‘–R_{F,i}\geq g_{i}(\mathbf{Q},\boldsymbol{\Omega}_{i}) in (17g). III. The constraints (17h) and (17i) on the numbers of local nLsubscriptğ‘›ğ¿n_{L} and global iterations nGsubscriptğ‘›ğºn_{G} come from (1) and (2). The constraint (17j) imposes the transmission power constraints at all IDs, and the last constraint (17k) rewrites (7).

To find an efficient solution of the non-convex problem (17), we propose an iterative algorithm, which repeatedly updates the optimization variables by solving the convex problems obtained by convexifying the non-convex functions. First, we replace the non-convex cost function in (17a) with an epigraph variable Ï„totalsubscriptğœtotal\tau_{\text{total}} constrained as

Ï„totalnGâ‰¥Ï„C+Ï„W+Ï„F.subscriptğœtotalsubscriptğ‘›ğºsubscriptğœğ¶subscriptğœğ‘Šsubscriptğœğ¹\displaystyle\frac{\tau_{\text{total}}}{n_{G}}\geq\tau_{C}+\tau_{W}+\tau_{F}. (18)

From [15, Prop. 1], the constraint (18) holds if there exists Î»totalsubscriptğœ†total\lambda_{\text{total}} satisfying

2â€‹Î»totalâ€‹Ï„total1/2âˆ’Î»total2â€‹nGâ‰¥Ï„C+Ï„W+Ï„F.2subscriptğœ†totalsuperscriptsubscriptğœtotal12superscriptsubscriptğœ†total2subscriptğ‘›ğºsubscriptğœğ¶subscriptğœğ‘Šsubscriptğœğ¹\displaystyle 2\lambda_{\text{total}}\tau_{\text{total}}^{1/2}-\lambda_{\text{total}}^{2}n_{G}\geq\tau_{C}+\tau_{W}+\tau_{F}. (19)

Note that (19) is a convex constraint if the auxiliary variable Î»totalsubscriptğœ†total\lambda_{\text{total}} is fixed. Also, the optimal Î»totalsubscriptğœ†total\lambda_{\text{total}} that makes (19) equivalent to (18) is given as

Note that problem (29) is tackled with respect to ğ~â‰œ[[ğ~E,k]kâˆˆğ’©Iâ€‹[ğ~C,k]kâˆˆğ’©I]â‰œ~ğdelimited-[]subscriptdelimited-[]subscript~ğğ¸ğ‘˜ğ‘˜subscriptğ’©ğ¼subscriptdelimited-[]subscript~ğğ¶ğ‘˜ğ‘˜subscriptğ’©ğ¼\tilde{\mathbf{Q}}\triangleq[[\tilde{\mathbf{Q}}_{E,k}]_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}}[\tilde{\mathbf{Q}}_{C,k}]_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}}] instead of ğğ\mathbf{Q}. We summarize the detailed algorithm in Algorithm 1. Because the optimal completion time Ï„totalsubscriptğœtotal\tau_{\text{total}} is not divergent, the solution of Algorithm 1 converges to a locally optimal point111We leave the development of an efficient algorithm that finds a global optimal solution of problem (17) as a future work. of the problem (29). In Step 6, ethsubscriptğ‘’the_{\text{th}} indicates the threshold value for judging the convergence in terms of cost function value, and tmaxsubscriptğ‘¡t_{\max} is the maximum allowed number of iterations. After convergence, each transmit covariance matrix ğm,ksubscriptğğ‘šğ‘˜\mathbf{Q}_{m,k} is obtained as ğm,kâ†ğ~m,kâ€‹ğ~m,kHâ†subscriptğğ‘šğ‘˜subscript~ğğ‘šğ‘˜superscriptsubscript~ğğ‘šğ‘˜ğ»\mathbf{Q}_{m,k}\leftarrow\tilde{\mathbf{Q}}_{m,k}\tilde{\mathbf{Q}}_{m,k}^{H} for mâˆˆ{E,C}ğ‘šğ¸ğ¶m\in\{E,C\}, kâˆˆğ’©Iğ‘˜subscriptğ’©ğ¼k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}.

The complexity of Algorithm 1 is the product of the number of iterations and the complexity of each iteration, i.e., Steps 3, 4, and 5. The latter is dominated by the complexity required to solve the convex problem at Step 4, i.e., the convex problem obtained by fixing {ğš²,ğšª,ğš¯,ğšº}ğš²ğšªğš¯ğšº\{\boldsymbol{\Lambda},\boldsymbol{\Gamma},\boldsymbol{\Theta},\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\} in problem (29). It was shown in [17, p. 4] that the worst-case complexity of finding a solution of a generic convex optimization problem is given as ğ’ªâ€‹(nvâ€‹(nv3+nc)â€‹logâ¡(1/Ïµ))ğ’ªsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘£superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘£3subscriptğ‘›ğ‘1italic-Ïµ\mathcal{O}(n_{v}(n_{v}^{3}+n_{c})\log(1/\epsilon)). Here nvsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘£n_{v} indicates the number of optimization variables, ncsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{c} denotes the number of arithmetic operations required to compute the objective and constraint functions, and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon represents the desired error tolerance level. The numbers nvsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘£n_{v} and ncsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{c} for the convex problem of Step 4 are given as nv=ğ’ªâ€‹(maxâ¡{MI2â€‹NI,MA2â€‹NA})subscriptğ‘›ğ‘£ğ’ªsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ¼2subscriptğ‘ğ¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ´2subscriptğ‘ğ´n_{v}=\mathcal{O}(\max\{M_{I}^{2}N_{I},M_{A}^{2}N_{A}\}) and nc=ğ’ªâ€‹(MA2â€‹NA2â€‹MI2â€‹NI)subscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ’ªsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ´2superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ´2superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ¼2subscriptğ‘ğ¼n_{c}=\mathcal{O}(M_{A}^{2}N_{A}^{2}M_{I}^{2}N_{I}), respectively. The number of iterations required for convergence is determined by the convergence rate, but its analysis for general successive convex approximation algorithms is still an open problem and is left as a future work.

V Numerical Results

We evaluate the performance of the fog-RAN-assisted FL system which adopts the proposed optimized rate-splitting scheme and compare with the following schemes: Edge-decoding only (dE,k=dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ¸ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{E,k}=d_{k}, âˆ€kâˆˆğ’©Ifor-allğ‘˜subscriptğ’©ğ¼\forall k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}) and cloud-decoding only schemes (dE,k=0subscriptğ‘‘ğ¸ğ‘˜0d_{E,k}=0, âˆ€kâˆˆğ’©Ifor-allğ‘˜subscriptğ’©ğ¼\forall k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}). IDs and APs are randomly distributed within an area of radius 200 m while satisfying the minimum separation of 10 m. The Rayleigh fading model is adopted as ğ‡i,k=Ï0â€‹(disti,k/dist0)âˆ’Î³/2â€‹ğ‡~i,ksubscriptğ‡ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğœŒ0superscriptsubscriptdistğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptdist0ğ›¾2subscript~ğ‡ğ‘–ğ‘˜\mathbf{H}_{i,k}=\rho_{0}(\text{dist}_{i,k}/\text{dist}_{0})^{-\gamma/2}\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{i,k} where disti,ksubscriptdistğ‘–ğ‘˜\text{dist}_{i,k} is the distance between ID kğ‘˜k and AP iğ‘–i, Ï0=10subscriptğœŒ010\rho_{0}=10 dB stands for the path-loss at reference distance dist0=50subscriptdist050\text{dist}_{0}=50 m, and the small-scale fading ğ‡~i,ksubscript~ğ‡ğ‘–ğ‘˜\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{i,k} is distributed as vecâ€‹(ğ‡~i,k)âˆ¼ğ’â€‹ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,ğˆ)similar-tovecsubscript~ğ‡ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ’ğ’©0ğˆ\text{vec}(\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{i,k})\sim\mathcal{CN}(\mathbf{0},\mathbf{I}). The parameters of local computing tasks are set to Dk=500subscriptğ·ğ‘˜500D_{k}=500, dk=28â‹…103subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜â‹…28superscript103d_{k}=28\cdot 10^{3}, ck=3â‹…109subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜â‹…3superscript109c_{k}=3\cdot 10^{9}, and nCâˆˆ{200,2000}subscriptğ‘›ğ¶2002000n_{C}\in\{200,2000\} [3, 4, 6]. We also fix Ptx/Ïƒz2=10subscriptğ‘ƒtxsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘§210P_{\text{tx}}/\sigma_{z}^{2}=10 dB, B=20ğµ20B=20 MHz, (MI,MA)=(1,2)subscriptğ‘€ğ¼subscriptğ‘€ğ´12({M_{I},M_{A}})=(1,2), and Î·G=10âˆ’3subscriptğœ‚ğºsuperscript103\eta_{G}=10^{-3} unless stated otherwise.

Fig. 2 depicts the average completion time ğ”¼â€‹[Ï„total]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğœtotal\mathbb{E}[\tau_{\text{total}}] versus the fronthaul capacity CFsubscriptğ¶ğ¹C_{F} for NI=10subscriptğ‘ğ¼10N_{I}=10, NAâˆˆ{2,3}subscriptğ‘ğ´23N_{A}\in\{2,3\}, and nC=200subscriptğ‘›ğ¶200n_{C}=200. The performance of all schemes is improved with a larger CFsubscriptğ¶ğ¹C_{F} due to the savings in the fronthaul latency Ï„Fsubscriptğœğ¹\tau_{F}. The cloud-decoding scheme gets more benefit than the edge-decoding scheme thanks to more pronounced impact of cooperative cloud detection. For all simulated scenarios, the rate-splitting transmission with the proposed optimization algorithm provides relevant gains compared to the baseline schemes. The gain over the cloud-decoding scheme is more significant for the case with less APs, in which the impact of cooperative cloud decoding would be marginal.

Fig. 3 plots the average optimized local accuracy level ğ”¼â€‹[Î·L]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğœ‚ğ¿\mathbb{E}[\eta_{L}] with respect to the fronthaul capacity CFsubscriptğ¶ğ¹C_{F} for the same setup in Fig. 2. As CFsubscriptğ¶ğ¹C_{F} increases, the impact of the fronthaul latency Ï„Fsubscriptğœğ¹\tau_{F} on the completion time (3) decreases. Thus, it is desirable to choose a larger local accuracy level Î·Lsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿\eta_{L} to suppress the computation time Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C}. In a similar vein, the optimized local accuracy of the rate-splitting scheme is larger than those of the baseline schemes, since it requires shorter transmission times Ï„Wsubscriptğœğ‘Š\tau_{W} and Ï„Fsubscriptğœğ¹\tau_{F}, which lead to a larger dominance of the computation time Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C} than the other schemes.

In Fig. 4, we plot the average completion time ğ”¼â€‹[Ï„total]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğœtotal\mathbb{E}[\tau_{\text{total}}] versus the number NAsubscriptğ‘ğ´N_{A} of APs for NI=7subscriptğ‘ğ¼7N_{I}=7, (MI,MA)=(2,2)subscriptğ‘€ğ¼subscriptğ‘€ğ´22(M_{I},M_{A})=(2,2), nC=200subscriptğ‘›ğ¶200n_{C}=200, CF=500subscriptğ¶ğ¹500C_{F}=500 Mbps, B=100ğµ100B=100 MHz, and Ptx/Ïƒz2âˆˆ{0,15}subscriptğ‘ƒtxsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘§2015P_{\text{tx}}/\sigma_{z}^{2}\in\{0,15\} dB. The cloud-decoding strategy outperforms the edge-decoding scheme when there are many APs due to more effective interference management capability enabled by joint decoding at CS. However, if only a few APs are involved, the edge-decoding scheme shows lower latency, which means that the impact of quantization noise signals of the cloud-decoding scheme cannot be counter-balanced by the advantage of cooperative decoding among small number of APs.

VI Conclusion

We have studied a fog-RAN-assisted FL system with finite-capacity fronthaul links. To enable flexible hybrid edge and cloud decoding strategies, we have proposed a rate-splitting transmission scheme and have tackled the problem of minimizing the completion time of FL with a given target global accuracy requirement. Via numerical results, we have checked the performance gain of the proposed optimized rate-splitting scheme over benchmark schemes and observed the impacts of various system parameters on the performance gains and the optimized local accuracy level. Among interesting open problems, we mention the optimization of global accuracy level and identifying its relation to test accuracy in actual learning tasks.
